p: Plants with a higher essential oil content ( Origanum vulgare subsp. hirtum, Origanum vulgare subsp. glandulosum and Origanum vulgare subsp. gracile) are characterized by the presence of carvacrol, thymol, p-cymene, and Î³-terpinene, while the ones with lower content by the presence of sabinene, linalool, borneol, and sesquiterpenes [ 22]. The extensive investigation of O. vulgare essential oil led to the conclusion that the remarkable chemical variability of oregano can be explained by the up-/down regulation of the metabolic biosynthetic pathways. This research substantiated the fact that chemotype composition is in direct correlation with the climatic factors, with plants from the Mediterranean climate presenting an active cymyl- and/or linalool pathway, while plants growing in areas characterized by Continental climate are poorer in monoterpenes and display a more active sabinyl-pathway [ 23].
